CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Criminal proceedings;Article 6-1 - Fair hearing;Impartial tribunal;Independent tribunal);Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and was serving his prison sentence in FAC at the time of his application to the ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested and taken into police custody by the Anti - terror branch of ORG on suspicion of his involvement in an illegal organisation , namely the ORG ( ORG ) .

CARDINAL . According to the search protocol drafted on DATE by police officers and signed by the applicant ’s father , the police , after obtaining his consent , searched the applicant ’s GPE flat and did not find any incriminating evidence .

CARDINAL . According to the search and seizure protocol drafted on DATE by the police officers and signed by the applicant , the police searched the applicant ’s flat and had found inside a book a paper with coded inscriptions and numbers on it . Following the search the applicant was taken back to the police station . However , QUANTITY police officers remained in the applicant ’s flat , until TIME , in case other members of the illegal organisation appeared .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s representative requested the public prosecutor at ORG to give her permission to see the applicant in police custody . On DATE the public prosecutor refused .
CARDINAL . Also DATE , the applicant was examined by a doctor at ORG . The applicant complained that he had been beaten . However , the doctor found no physical evidence of illtreatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was brought before the public prosecutor at ORG . Before the public prosecutor the applicant gave information as to his relations with various people but denied that he had been involved in an illegal organisation and that he had taken part in military training in GPE . He claimed that he did not know anything about the code found during the search . He acknowledged that he knew Mr A.T and Mr U.M who had identified him in the police station . He submitted further that he knew Mr A.E.K. , PERSON , and Mr PERSON because they were in the same prison as his sister . He admitted that Mr ORG and Mr ORG knew him as PERSON but stated that this was not a code name .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was brought , together with CARDINAL other suspects , before ORG . He refuted the statements he had given to the police and reiterated his statements made to the public prosecutor . The other suspects claimed that they knew the applicant as “ PERSON and acknowledged their statements given to the police and to the public prosecutor . The court ordered the applicant ’s remand in custody .

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor at ORG filed a bill of indictment with that court , accusing the applicant of membership of an illegal organisation , namely the ORG . The public prosecutor requested that the applicant be convicted and sentenced under LAW § CARDINAL and LAW no . ORG .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date ORG commenced the trial against the applicant and CARDINAL other co - accused .

CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE the applicant stated that he was not a member of the ORG and that he did not accept the content of the statements he had given to the police since they had been extracted under duress and torture . The statements which the applicant had made to the public prosecutor were read out to him . He rectified certain details . He further submitted that he had asked his brother for money but since he did not have an identity document and a bank account , his brother had sent the money to the bank account of Mr PERSON He was asked PERSON , who had sent the money to PERSON He stated that he did not know PERSON personally but that she was a friend of his brother . He maintained that he did not have a code name and that people knew him as “ PERSON ” because that was his middle name . As to the coded inscriptions , he claimed that the police made him write them in the police station . The search and seizure protocol was read out to him . He denied that the coded inscriptions had been found in his house .

CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE the applicant requested that witnesses on his behalf be heard by the court . The court , taking into account the evidence contained in the case file and the fact that the witness PERSON was living in GPE , decided not to hear the latter witness . On the other hand , the court decided to hear the other witnesses . On DATE the court heard the applicant ’s witnesses .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted his final written defence submissions to the court . He claimed that there was no evidence in the case file to support the accusations against him apart from his statements given under duress in police custody . In particular , he alleged that the police had made him write the coded inscriptions while he was in custody .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG convicted the applicant as charged and sentenced him to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . The court held , inter alia , that as the applicant ’s statements in police custody were consistent with the statements made by PERSON , PERSON ORG , Mr ORG and Mr U.M. , it did not find the applicant ’s statements made during the trial convincing . As to the defence witnesses’ statements , the court ruled that , as the witnesses were the applicant ’s relatives , their submissions could not be considered reliable . The court further held that since the profile of the applicant did not match that given by CARDINAL convicted persons who had given evidence it did not take into account the latter ’s statements in its assessment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against the judgment of ORG . In his appeal petition , the applicant reiterated his previous submissions . He further argued that the court had relied on unlawfully obtained evidence and that there was no evidence to support the allegation that he was a member of an illegal organisation . The applicant also attached the written witness statement of PERSON to his petition . According to the written statement of PERSON , she was a friend of the applicant ’s brother and since he had been busy she had made all the necessary transactions and sent the money to the bank account given to her .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a hearing and upheld the judgment of ORG . The court pronounced its decision on DATE in the absence of the applicant and his representative . The applicant ’s representative claims that she learned of the decision of ORG on DATE when she went to that court on other business .
